{{Infobox venue | name = South Yorkshire Sports Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = Station Road, [[Wombwell]], near [[Barnsley]], [[South Yorkshire]] | coordinates = 53°31'36.5"N 1°23'32.8"W | opened = 1928 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1960s | owner = | operator = | surface = }}
'''South Yorkshire Sports Stadium''' was a [[Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom|greyhound racing]] and [[Motorcycle speedway|speedway]] stadium on Station Road in [[Wombwell]], near [[Barnsley]], [[South Yorkshire]]. It was one of two greyhound tracks in the town; the other was called the [[Wombwell Greyhound Stadium]].
==Origins== The South Yorkshire Sports Stadium was constructed north of Station Road, south of Bulling Dike and accessed on a small road called Kent Row at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.old-maps.co.uk/#/Map/440374/403516/12/101162|title=OS County Series Yorkshire 1931|publisher=old-maps.co.uk}}</ref>
==Opening== It opened unofficially on Saturday 17 April 1928 with 3,000 spectators raising £15 (the nights entrance fees) for local charities. One week later on Saturday 21 April 1928 the stadium officially opened charging 1/-, 2/- or 3/- for the relevant enclosures.<ref name=DM>{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}}</ref> Speedway followed in 1929.
==History== The greyhound racing was independent (not affiliated to the sports governing body the [[National Greyhound Racing Club]]) and was known as a flapping track which was the nickname given to independent tracks. The track was a popular venue with [[Tote board|totalisator turnover]] peaking in 1946 at £64,255.<ref>{{cite book|title=Particulars of Licensed tracks, table 1 Licensed Dog Racecourses|year=1946|publisher=Licensing Authorities}}</ref>
The greyhound racing finished during May 1956.<ref name=DM/>
==Speedway== Speedway was held sporadically from 1929-1965; the team were known as the [[Wombwell Colliers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defunctspeedway.co.uk/wombwell.htm|title=Wombwell Speedway|publisher=Defunct Speedway Tracks}}</ref>
The stadium was demolished and later became the Valley Road industrial area.

{{Infobox company | name = Torneos | logo = Logo Torneos.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]]| foundation = 1982| location = [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]| key_people = Ignacio Galarza,{{cite news|url=http://www.infobae.com/2015/06/22/1736990-torneos-y-competencias-nombro-al-sucesor-alejandro-burzaco|accessdate=16 February 2016}} CEO| industry = [[mass media|Media]]| products = [[Television]]| divisions = [[TyC Sports]]
[[Fox Sports Latinoamérica|Fox Sports]]
[[:es:DIRECTV Sports|DIRECTV Sports]]| homepage = {{URL|www.torneos.com}}| }} [[File:Torneos y Competencias TyC sede Monserrat.jpg|thumb|Head office]] '''Torneos y Competencias S.A.''' ('''TyC''', also referred as '''Torneos''') is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] sports communications firm created by businessman Carlos Ávila, who has left the company. It is an important force in the world of Argentine sports, with interests in publications and radio and TV broadcasting. Its headquarters are in [[Buenos Aires]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tyc.com.ar/corp/contacto.asp|title=Nuestras Oficinas se encuentran ubicadas en Balcarce 510, Ciudad de Buenos Aires, Argentina|publisher=Tyc.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|language=es|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150101002847/http://www.tyc.com.ar/corp/contacto.asp|archivedate=1 January 2015|df=}} ==History== Torneos started its activities in the Argentine media in 1982, with a [[golf]] program. Since then it produced and aired successful programs in network television such as ''El deporte y el hombre'', ''Tenis de Primera'', ''[[Football (soccer)|Fútbol]] de Primera'' and ''La Magia de la [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]''; the most successful of them being the weekly ''Fútbol de Primera'', which summarizes each day of competition in the [[Primera División Argentina|Argentine first division]]. In 1994, Torneos launched the channel [[TyC Sports]] to broadcast the [[Argentine Primera Division]]. ===Removal of first division television rights=== In 1992, the company Televisión Satelital Codificada (TSC, a [[joint venture]] between TyC and the [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]] group) signed an agreement with the [[Argentine Football Association]] (AFA) for the broadcasters exclusive live of Argentine [[Association football|football]] matches. All the official matches were available on the '''TyC Sports''' and '''TyC Max''' cable & satellite channels. This agreement will expire in 2014. In July 2009, due to an economic crisis that affected several [[Primera División Argentina|Primera División]] clubs, the AFA tried new ways of financing. The President of the AFA, [[Julio Grondona]], requested TSC authorities to modify the contract for television rights in order for the AFA to receive 720 million [[Argentine peso]]s. However, in the last season, TSC paid the AFA 230 million pesos, and the request was rejected by TSC.{{cite web|url=http://www.ole.clarin.com/notas/2009/08/04/futbollocal/01971526.html|title=Mirando otro canal|publisher=Ole.clarin.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|language=es}} Later, Grondona received an offer from the Argentine government in order for the National System of Public Media – the state-owned [[Channel 7 (Argentina)|Channel 7]] – to replace TSC for broadcasting the games on TV.{{cite web|url=http://www.losandes.com.ar/notas/2009/8/9/un-439587.asp|title=TyC denunci que hay un acuerdo para estatizar la televisacin del ftbol|author=Diario Los Andes|publisher=Losandes.com.ar|accessdate=25 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219191928/http://www.losandes.com.ar/notas/2009/8/9/un-439587.asp|archivedate=19 February 2012|df=}} [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]]'s government has a public confrontation against the Clarín group, a member of TSC.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/cultura_sociedad/2009/08/090811_argentina_futbol_grondona_rompe_gm.shtml|title=BBC Mundo - Cultura y Sociedad - El fútbol argentino cambia de canal|publisher=Bbc.co.uk|accessdate=25 November 2014|language=es}} On August 11, 2009, the AFA broke the contract with TSC, accusing it of not fulfilling the agreement.{{cite web|url=http://www.elargentino.com/nota-53419-La-AFA-rompio-el-contrato-con-TSC-y-reabre-el-juego-de-la-TV.html|title=INFOnews - El Argentino CABA - Un mundo, muchas voces|publisher=Elargentino.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|language=es|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304002727/http://www.elargentino.com/nota-53419-La-AFA-rompio-el-contrato-con-TSC-y-reabre-el-juego-de-la-TV.html|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} Then, the AFA sued TSC,{{cite web|url=http://www.perfil.com/contenidos/2009/08/14/noticia_0011.html|title=La AFA "entablará una demanda millonaria" contra TSC|work=Perfil.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|language=es}} but TyC also tried an unsuccessful lawsuit against the AFA for cancelling the contract.{{cite web|url=http://www.educacion.terra.com.ar/canales/politica/205/205014.html|title=Terra - La Justicia rechaz presentacin de TSC contra la AFA y habr ftbol> 14-8-2009 - Actualidad|publisher=Educacion.terra.com.ar|accessdate=25 November 2014|language=es|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303212301/http://www.educacion.terra.com.ar/canales/politica/205/205014.html|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=}} Evertithing Follow producing of the [[Primera B Nacional Argentina|Second]] and [[Primera B Metropolitana|Third Division]].[http://www.elsitiodealmagro.com.ar/modules/news/article.php?storyid=1529] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090821100739/http://www.elsitiodealmagro.com.ar/modules/news/article.php?storyid=1529 |date=August 21, 2009 }} Since August 21, 2009, the television rights for Argentine [[Primera División Argentina|Primera División]] belongs to the state-owned [[TV Pública Digital (Argentina)|TV Pública]].{{cite web|url=http://www.argentina.ar/_es/deporte/C2261-futbol-gratis-por-television.php|title=Argentina - Ftbol gratis por television|publisher=Argentina.ar|accessdate=25 November 2014|language=es}} The matches are carried by TVP and various stations in interior Argentina; the broadcasts are known as ''[[Fútbol para todos]]''.{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1519043-asignan-mas-fondos-al-futbol-para-todos-y-a-la-propaganda-oficial|title= Asignan más fondos al Fútbol para Todos y a la propaganda oficial|trans-title=|author= Laura Serra|date= October 20, 2012|work= |publisher= La Nación|accessdate=November 24, 2012|language=es}} ===Present=== On 30 March 2016 the [[Asociacion del Futbol Argentino|AFA]] approved the contract with the company that includes the [[Argentine Primera División]], [[Argentine Second Division]], [[Primera B Metropolitana]], [[Argentine Cup]], Argentina national football team's friendly and qualifiers games, and the international media rights, until 2019.{{cite news|title=Ajustes de números: AFA renegoció los contratos con Torneos|url=http://www.infobae.com/2016/03/30/1800817-ajustes-numeros-afa-renegocio-los-contratos-torneos-y-habra-mas-plata-ayudar-al-ascenso|accessdate=3 April 2016}} ==Management== Ignacio Galarza has been the CEO of Torneos since 2015. ===Shareholders=== Torneos current shareholders are: [[DirecTV Latin America|Vrio]] (40%), Luis Nofal Sports Holding (20%), the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] investment firm DLJ Offshore Partners (20%) and [[Alejandro Burzaco]] (20%).{{cite news|title=Alejandro Burzaco, el verdadero dueño del fútbol por TV|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1796554-alejandro-burzaco-torneos|accessdate=29 October 2016|agency=LA NACIÓN}} ==Channels== Torneos and the 34 South Media Group (before Clarín Group) in Argentina currently operate the domestic pay TV channel [[TyC Sports]], as well as two international pay TV channels '''TyC Sports Latin America''' and '''TyC Sports USA'''. Torneos also produces most sport shows for [[Fox Sports Latin America]] - South Cone, including the airing of [[Copa Libertadores]], [[Copa Sudamericana]], [[Formula One]] and many others. ==Exclusive Rights== The company’s television rights includes: [[Copa Libertadores]], [[Copa Sudamericana]], [[Recopa Sudamericana]], [[Argentine First Division]], [[Argentine Second Division]], [[Primera B Metropolitana]], [[Argentine Cup]], [[Argentine national football team]] friendlys and qualifiers games, international media rights and the Summer and Winter Tournaments from Mar del Plata, Salta, Mendoza and Córdoba (vía Fox Sports, Fox Sports Premium, Fox Sports 2, TNT Sports, TNT, TyC Sports and TyC Max). ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == External links== *{{es icon}} {{Official website|www.torneos.com}} [[Category:Television production companies of Argentina]] [[Category:Companies based in Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Sports companies]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |title = Zumba Fitness |image = Zumba-fitness-video-game.jpg |caption = |developer =[[Pipeworks Software]] |publisher=[[Majesco Entertainment]]
[[505 Games]] |engine = [[Spigot]] |released ={{vgrelease|NA|November 18, 2010|EU|November 26, 2010}} |genre =[[Exergaming|Fitness game]] |modes =[[Single-player video game|Single-player]]; [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]]; [[Multiplayer online game|Online multiplayer]] |platforms = [[PlayStation 3]], [[Wii]], [[Xbox 360]] }} '''''Zumba Fitness''''' is a video game[http://zumba-reviews.com/zumba-game/zumba-fitness-game-is-it-really-that-good Zumba Game Review] developed by [[Pipeworks Software]] and published by [[Majesco Entertainment]] based on the [[Zumba]] program. It is available for [[Wii]], [[PlayStation 3]] with [[PlayStation Move]], and [[Xbox 360]] with [[Kinect]]. The Wii and PS3 versions come with a Zumba Belt where the Wii Remote or Move controller is inserted into on the right hip. The game was released in November 2010. ==Gameplay== The game supports up to four players on [[Wii]] and [[PlayStation Move]], up to two players on [[Kinect]], locally, and up to eight players [[Multiplayer online game|online]] on [[PlayStation Move]] and [[Kinect]]. ==Sequel== Due to successful sales of the game, Majesco has scheduled a [[Zumba Fitness 2|second game]] for the Wii which was released on November 15, 2011. The second game adds music tracks by popular artists such as [[Pitbull (rapper)|Pitbull]] and [[Nicole Scherzinger]].[http://zumbafitnessgame.com/zumba2.pdf Majesco Press Release]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Instructors== Gina, Tanya and [[Beto Perez|Beto]] are the Zumba Fitness Instructors. Gina for the Beginner Level, Tanya for the Intermediate Levels, and Beto for the Expert Levels and the Zumbathon. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/majesco-entertainment-provides-details-of-zumba-fitness-video-game-96337804.html Press release] {{Zumba}} [[Category:2010 video games]] [[Category:Dance video games]] [[Category:Exergames]] [[Category:Kinect games]] [[Category:Majesco Entertainment games]] [[Category:Multiplayer online games]] [[Category:Music video games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Move-compatible games]] [[Category:Unreal Engine games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Wii Balance Board games]] [[Category:Wii MotionPlus games]] [[Category:Wii Speak games]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] {{sports-videogame-stub}}
